awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Periodic Orbits of Hamiltonian Diffeomorphisms and Reeb Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Hamiltonian systems constitute a broad class of mechanical systems where energy dissipation can be neglected. For example, the planetary motion in celestial mechanics, the flow of an incompressible ideal fluid, and the motion of a charged particle in an electro-magnetic field are usually treated as Hamiltonian dynamical systems. One of the most important questions concerning the dynamics of such systems and connected to many other branches of mathematics and physics is the existence of periodic orbits. Corresponding to cyclic motion, this is the simplest dynamical phenomenon after equilibrium, and an investigation of periodic orbits of a system is crucial in understanding its global behavior. To give but a few applications, the knowledge of periodic orbits is crucial in astronomy, particle accelerators, and fluid dynamics or can be used to understand stability of solutions for large times. Hamiltonian systems tend to have numerous periodic orbits, but proving the existence of even one closed orbit often requires advanced and powerful mathematical tools. This research project aims at establishing the existence of infinitely many periodic orbits for a broad class of Hamiltonian systems and analyzing the systems that fall outside this class, and the work will advance our understanding of the dynamics of conservative systems and result in the development of new powerful techniques applicable to other questions. Many of the systems considered in the proposal (e.g., magnetic flows) are of interest in physics and engineering, and some of the projects are expected to have applications in mathematical physics, geometric mechanics, and other areas.

The research program focuses on the question of the existence of infinitely many periodic orbits for Hamiltonian dynamical systems in a variety of settings and on new methods to investigate this question that are currently being developed by the PI. The research comprises several interconnected projects addressing various aspects of this question for certain classes of Hamiltonian diffeomorphisms and Reeb flows and also for specific Hamiltonian systems such as magnetic flows. The project also opens up new research directions such as the study of non-contractible periodic orbits on closed manifolds. The PI will tackle these problems employing symplectic topological methods including Floer and quantum homological techniques, contact and symplectic homology, J-holomorphic curves, and spectral invariants, and will continue to develop new Floer theoretic techniques tailored for the study of periodic orbits. The projects have applications to other questions of interest in symplectic and contact dynamics and topology, classical dynamical systems, and Riemannian geometry.

por.por_cntn:
The proposed research lies at the interface between symplectic topology and Hamiltonian dynamical systems. Its primary goal is to establish the existence of infinitely many simple periodic orbits for a broad class of Hamiltonian systems (Hamiltonian diffeomorphisms and Reeb flows) and analyze the systems that fall outside this class, thereby advancing our understanding of the dynamics of conservative systems. Yet the work carried out has gone beyond that scope, investigating Hamiltonian systems from various other perspectives (invariant sets, entropy, rigidity, etc.) using symplectic topological methods combined with tools from other areas (e.g., integral geometry, dynamical systems, h-principles, topological data analysis) as well as developing new techniques pertinent to this study.

Hamiltonian systems constitute a broad class of dynamical systems where energy dissipation can be neglected. For example, the planetary motion in celestial mechanics, the flow of an incompressible ideal fluid and the motion of a charged particle in an electro-magnetic field are usually treated as Hamiltonian dynamical systems. One of the most important questions concerning the dynamics of such systems and connected to many other branches of mathematics and physics is the existence of periodic orbits. Corresponding to the cyclic motion, this is the simplest dynamical phenomenon after equilibrium, and an investigation of periodic orbits of a system is crucial in understanding its global behavior. To name a few applications, the knowledge of periodic orbits is crucial in astronomy, particle accelerators, fluid dynamics, and in understanding the long-term stability of solutions. Hamiltonian systems tend to have numerous periodic orbits, but proving the existence of even one closed orbit often requires advanced and powerful mathematical tools.

 The project has led to several key outcomes. First, a series of results has established the existence of infinitely many simple periodic orbits for a variety of Hamiltonian systems (some general and some specific such as strong magnetic flows) and for higher dimensional Reeb flows it has put the multiplicity question in a broad and conceptual perspective via a contact variant of the Lusternik­-Schnirelmann theory. Second, the project has started a new research direction focusing on the study of Hamiltonian systems with the minimal number of periodic points (pseudo-rotations) in higher dimensions via Floer theory. Key outcomes in this direction include, for instance, a proof of the Lagrangian Poincare recurrence conjecture and a higher dimensional Le Calvez-Yoccoz theorem for pseudo-rotations of complex projective spaces. The work has also resulted in a fairly conclusive topological criterion for a symplectic manifold to admit a Hamiltonian system with finitely many simple periodic orbits and connected this phenomenon to the symplectic topology of the ambient manifold (existence of non-vanishing Gromov-Witten invariants), resulting a proof of the notoriously difficult Chance-McDuff conjecture for pseudo-rotations. Going beyond its original scope, the work has also investigated dynamics phenomena beyond periodic orbits from a Floer theoretic perspective using tools from topological data analysis and integral geometry but also developing novel techniques. Most notably, the PI and her collaborators introduced the notion of “barcode entropy”, an entropy-type invariant measuring the exponential growth rate of chaos in a Hamiltonian system, and showed that this invariant is closely related to topological entropy, a well-known fundamental invariant measuring the complexity of a dynamical system. The ideas and new tools stemming from this work have been used to study other questions such as the continuity properties of the Riemannian volume of Lagrangian submanifolds with respect to the spectral norm and establishing uniform lower bounds on the spectral norm under iterations of a Hamiltonian diffeomorphism. In the long term, the results of the project may potentially have applications in topological data analysis and image recognition.

The broader impact aspects of the project mainly lie in the areas of education (in particular, integrating research and education) and dissemination of knowledge. Throughout the award period, the PI has mentored a number of students at all levels and from various backgrounds; given lecture series, incorporating new findings, targeted for graduate and advanced undergraduate students; and communicated the research results via seminar and conference talks in addition to journal publications and arXiv preprints. The PI also co-organized several workshops focusing on the general research directions of the project where groups traditionally underrepresented in mathematics were supported with high priority.
